block.p: Aetna U.S. Healthcare will change its payment system for all its primary care doctors in Connecticut in an effort to improve relations with physicians in Connecticut, Aetna officials said yesterday.

Aetna announced in May that for physicians with 100 or fewer Aetna clients, it would abandon the current program, which pays primary care physicians a fixed amount per patient each month, regardless of the time spent with a patient. Aetna U.S. Healthcare will change its payment system for all its primary care doctors in Connecticut in an effort to improve relations with physicians in Connecticut, Aetna officials said yesterday.

Aetna announced in May that for physicians with 100 or fewer Aetna clients, it would abandon the current program, which pays primary care physicians a fixed amount per patient each month, regardless of the time spent with a patient. The original announcement would have affected about 70 percent of Aetna's 1,800 network doctors in Connecticut.
But Aetna decided to pay all doctors on a fee-for-service basis to simplify administration for physicians and Aetna, said Dr. Gordon W. Grundy, network medical director for Connecticut.
Dr. Grundy said the change would not affect patients, but would help the insurer recruit new doctors.
Aetna will also drop its requirement that participating doctors serve all of Aetna's health plans, including HMO's.
